explanation: Set of rules and protocols for communication between software systems, used to exchange data or trigger transactions in banking platforms.
Main architectural styles for APIs; REST is preferred in banking for stateless interactions and simplicity.
Entity authorized under open banking to access and aggregate financial data from multiple banks.
Individual or entity that uses financial services via API-enabled banking or fintech platforms.
Multilayer authentication method using two or more factors to validate user identity per PSD2 regulation.
Batch-based network for electronic funds transfers between banks, supporting payroll, bill payments, and direct deposits.
Electronic funds transfer between banks via payment rails (SWIFT, SEPA, FedWire), typically for high-value or cross-border payments.
Underlying network or protocol for moving money (e.g., ACH, card networks, SWIFT); affects speed, cost, and compliance.
Regulatory process for verifying user identities to prevent fraud and meet compliance obligations.
Regulatory framework for detecting, reporting, and preventing financial crime and suspicious activity.
Industry standard for securing credit card data during processing, transmission, and storage.
API design property ensuring repeated requests yield the same result, crucial for financial operations to prevent duplication.
Protocol for secure API authorization using access tokens and scopes without exposing passwords.
Credential for accessing secured APIs, typically short-lived and scoped to user/session permissions.
Measure of API availability; critical banking interfaces target near-perfect ('five nines') uptime.
Bank that processes merchant payments and routes them to the relevant networks.
Bank or institution that issues payment cards to consumers and handles authorization.
Transfer of funds between institutions after transaction authorization
